column1: Nea Salamis Famagusta FC or Nea Salamina Famagusta FC (Greek: Νέα Σαλαμίνα Αμμοχώστου) is a professional football club based in Ammochostos (also known by its romanized name
column2: Famagusta)
column3: Cyprus. It has been a refugee club since the 1974 Turkish invasion of Cyprus
column4: when Turkey occupied the northern part of the island. The club is temporarily based in Larnaca.

column1: Nea Salamina's most notable achievements were its victories in the Cypriot Cup and the Cypriot Super Cup in 1990. Its highest finish in the Cypriot First Division is third place. During its first five years (1948–1953)
column2: the team participated in the Cyprus Amateur Football Federation championships. In 1953 the club joined the Cyprus Football Association (CFA)
column3: participating regularly in association championships and cup competitions. It has played in more than 50 Cypriot First Division seasons
column4: ranking seventh in that category.

column1: The team participated for the first time in European competition in 1990 at the European Cup Winners' Cup
column2: and played in the 1995
column3: 1997 and 2000 UEFA Intertoto Cups. The team is part of the Nea Salamina Famagusta sports club
column4: which was founded in 1948; the parent club also fields a men's volleyball team. The club is named after the ancient city of Cyprus
column5: Salamis or Salamina
column6: which is located nearby modern Famagusta ("Nea" means "new" in Greek language).

column1: When Nea Salamina Famagusta was founded
column2: Greece was entering a period of civil war between leftists and rightists. The situation in Greece affected Cyprus
column3: both politically and socially; most athletes were also involved in politics. At this time
column4: Famagusta had two sports clubs: the Evagoras Gymnastic Association
column5: or GSE (Greek: Γυμναστικός Σύλλογος Ευαγόρας) and the Anorthosis Famagusta FC. The GSE had many talented leftist athletes on its rosters. At Anorthosis
column6: many players were also leftists. Under the influence of the contemporary right-wing political climate
column7: the GSE and Anorthosis began to restrict leftist athletes. Additionally
column8: Anorthosis was hosting at their clubhouse the right-wing Cypriot National Party. In early 1947 a group from Famagusta (including leftists
column9: members and non-members of GSE and Anorthosis) concluded there was room for another sports club in the city. Due to the existing restrictions
column10: they envisioned a club which would appeal to everyone in Famagusta regardless of political affiliation.On 14 February 1948 the decision was made to establish the club
column11: and the Nea Salamina sports club was formed on 7 March 1948 as the first leftist athletic club in Cyprus. After the club's founding
column12: many citizens expressed a desire to join; however

column1: === GSE Stadium banning and the CAFF ===
Before the Pancyprian Games in May 1948
column2: the Hellenic Amateur Athletic Association (SEGAS) asked all gymnastics associations in Cyprus
column3: their members and athletes
column4: to sign a public declaration that would express their support to the rightists in Greek Civil War

column1: to declare that they espoused "nationalist beliefs" and to repudiate the leftists. The right-wing athletic clubs and athletes signed the statements; the only club refusing to sign the statement was the Kinyras Paphos gymnastic association
column2: which was excluded from the games. The left-wing athletes were opposed to the declaration
column3: and refused to sign the statement. Among the first athletes who refused were GSE champions Antonis Totsis (Greek: Αντώνης Τότσης) and Nikis Georgiou (Greek: Νικής Γεωργίου). The GSE invited both athletes to apologize
column4: but they insisted on their position that sports should be separate from politics. The left-wing athletes decided to support the Kinyras Paphos association if the decision to exclude it from the Pancyprian Games stood. The GSE was favored to win the competition
column5: but finished third. As a reaction to the fact that athletes of Nea Salamina were not involved in the Pancyprian Games
column6: the GSE president informed the club it was not welcome at the GSE Stadium. Persecution of GSE and Anorthosis athletes who supported their teammates followed. The stadium-use prohibition meant that Nea Salamina had nowhere to play.Negative attitudes toward left-wing athletes prevailed in other Cypriot cities. In Larnaca
column7: the Alki Larnaca F.C. was founded in April 1948. A month later
column8: the Gymnastics Club Zeno (GSZ) banned Alki from using its GSZ Stadium; a similar proposal to exclude Turks and Catholics was rejected. The GSZ amended its constitution
column9: prohibiting enrollment of new members unless they signed a declaration that "they espouse the Hellenic nationalistic ideals". This excluded left-wing athletes from becoming members or using its stadium. In May
column10: Orfeas Nicosia was founded in Nicosia; that month
column11: APOEL F.C. sent a greeting by telegram to SEGAS ("cordial brotherly greetings to the entire Greek youth athletes")
column12: on the occasion of national games
column13: and wished for the cessation of inner-nation mutiny. APOEL asked all members and athletes of the club to sign a declaration
column14: supporting the content of the telegram. Leftist members and athletes of APOEL considered "inner-nation mutiny" as a challenge and political statement of the club
column15: thus they distanced themselves from that statement. The Cypriot press encouraged a hostile climate with articles and commentary. This was followed by the indefinite suspension of five APOEL athletes (Lympouris
column19: who founded AC Omonia in June 1948 with former members of the APOEL. AS Kyrenia was later founded.Due to their left-wing political beliefs
column20: members of the new clubs were not accepted into the Cyprus Football Association (CFA) and they established a new football federation (the Cyprus Amateur Football Federation
column21: or CAFF) in December 1948. The new federation organized leagues and cups
column22: which attracted thousands of fans. The CAFF matches became more popular than those of the CFA. Six teams belonged to the CAFF: Nea Salamina in Famagusta
column25: AMOL at Limassol (renamed Antaeus in 1951) and Neos Asteras in Morphou.

column1: CAFF members favored the unification of football in Cyprus. They tried for three years to persuade the CFA to accept them as members
column2: without success. The existence of two football federations (with two separate championships) in a country such as Cyprus was unprecedented. The situation created economic hardship
column3: and hampered the development and improvement of Cypriot football. The clubs felt that sports should reflect fraternity and friendship rather than discrimination. In December 1952
column4: the first issue of the sports newspaper Athlitiki supported the unification of Cypriot football. Foreign coaches of CFA clubs also supported unification
column5: leading the CFA to respond that "their statements opposed the spirit of the Federation". Coaches of CFA's teams were initially hostile towards consolidation supporters. In summer 1953
column6: the majority of Cypriot sportspeople expressed support for football unification. In August of that year Nea Salamina
column8: Alki and Antaeus submitted a joint application to the CFA to join the Cypriot First Division. On 19 September
column9: the CFA accepted Nea Salamina and Omonia for membership. However
column10: the organization's negative attitude towards those clubs continued. First
column11: the league rejected applications from Alki
column12: Orfeas Nicosia and Neos Asteras (although the first two joined a year later)
column14: arguing that according to its constitution
column15: only one team must participate in the Cypriot First Division and two teams in the second division. The CAFF clubs accepted these conditions in the interest of unification. In an ad hoc meeting of CAFF
column16: members agreed that Omonia would join the first division and Nea Salamina and Antaeus the second division. Following these decisions
column17: CAFF disbanded. The first game between teams from the two federations (a friendly) was played by Nea Salamina and Anorthosis at GSE Stadium on 27 September 1953. 5
column18: 200 fans were present at the game between the two Famagustian clubs. The final result was 3–1 in favor of Anorthosis
column19: and the match was described as an evidence of superior sportsmanship and brotherhood of fans by Athlitiki.

column1: After being denied access to the GSE stadium
column2: the club did not have a venue for training. They initially practiced at the Saint Lukas pitch (Proodou) in Famagusta and began efforts to build a privately owned stadium. In December 1948 Israel made a CYP£3
column3: 000 donation to the city of Famagusta
column4: in gratitude for aid by its inhabitants to Jewish refugees
column5: for a community-service project. Gabriel Makris
column6: a Famagusta alderman and Nea Salamina footballer
column7: supported the association's recommendation to build the stadium. The city council recognized the "financial assistance granted to the Jews to create Municipal Sports Stadium
column8: which is available to Famagustans for the promotion and spread of mass popular sport". The stadium was available to Nea Salamina and other sports clubs.In early 1949
column9: volunteer construction work began on a municipal stadium in Saint John Famagusta parish. The stadium—the first in Cyprus with a roof over the stands—was built by supporters of the club and footballers and completed in 1952. It served as Nea Salamina's headquarters from 1952 to 1953.In 1953
column10: after the unification of football federations
column11: Nea Salamina used GSE Stadium. The city's Municipal Stadium was used by the team for training. This period lasted until 1974
column12: when Famagusta was occupied by the Turkish Army after the Turkish invasion in Cyprus and the club was forced to move its headquarters.

column3: Municipal Stadium in Deryneia and Antonis Papadopoulos Stadium in Larnaca. In 1991 the team built its own stadium
column4: Ammochostos Stadium.

column1: Nea Salamina's emblem incorporates the Olympic flame
column2: the color red and the five rings of the Olympic Games. The club's colors during its first two years were yellow and crimson
column3: when it was part of the Cyprus Amateur Football Federation. After 1950
column4: the governing council changed its colors to red and white: red symbolizing power
column5: and white symbolizing peace. Red-and-white striped jerseys were chosen because they resembled those worn by Olympiacos Piraeus.

column1: After the 1953 unification of Cypriot football

column3: and the Famagusta Municipal Stadium was used for training. The second division had two groups; Nea Salamina was in the Nicosia-Larnaca-Famagusta group. The group winner faced the winner of the Limassol-Paphos group for promotion to first division. Nea Salamina finished second in its group

column9: with Nea Salamina playing in the Larnaca-Famagusta group. With the conquest of the first position in the group

column12: and the champion of the Nicosia group
column14: in a new three teams championships. Nea Salamina finished in first place. During the same period
column16: excluded from subsequent phases one of the strongest teams of the season

column1: During the early years of the decade
column2: Nea Salamina was strong in home games but weak away. Noteworthy is the conquest of the amateur championship from farm team the period 1960–61
column3: The games of the farm team gathered the same interest with the main team among fans
column4: who enthusiastically celebrated winning the title. During this period the nucleus for a successful team was created
column5: including Kyriakos Koureas (who later played for Olympiakos Piraeus). In December 1963
column6: the league disbanded; at that time
column7: Nea Salamina was in a tight three-way race with Omonia and APOEL. With the creation of Cypriot National Guard
column8: many Nea Salamina's players joined the army; players would often come straight from camps throughout Cyprus to play league games with no training.

column1: The 1965–66 season was one of the best (but painful) periods for Nea Salamina; the team arguably played the best football in Cyprus. The team contended for the championship until the last game of the season and lose its first cup final. In a game against APOEL at the old GSP stadium
column2: Nea Salamina was leading 3–0. In the 62nd minute
column3: an APOEL player hit a Nea Salamina's player; an APOEL grabbed and hid a linesman's flag. The game was halted
column4: and the CFA ordered a rematch. The dispute lasted more than three weeks; in the meantime Nea Salamina was defeated by the bottommost team
column5: Aris Limassol F.C.. In the penultimate match of the tournament Omonia and Salamina were tied for first place on points
column6: and Olympiacos was one point behind. In the game against Olympiakos Nicosia Nea Salamina was leading 2–1
column7: but Olympiakos tied the game in allegedly excessive extra time. After clashes in the last few seconds
column8: the game was halted and ordered replayed. Omonia was in first place with 50 points; Nea Salamina was second with 47 and Olympiakos third with 46. With a victory over Olympiakos Nea Salamina would win the championship
column9: since it had more goals than Omonia. On 31 May 1966 many buses and cars drove from Famagusta to Nicosia
column10: where Nea Salamina was defeated 6–3. The best defense in the league
column11: which had allowed fifteen goals in nineteen games
column12: allowed six in one game. For a second time
column13: Nea Salamina finished third. This defeat affected team morale in the cup final with rival Apollon Limassol; although it was favored
column14: the team lost 4–2. During this period Salamina had the best defense in the league
column15: with 21 goals in 20 games (a team record).Near the end of the 1966–67 season the board of Olympiakos reported rumors of future match-fixing between Nea Salamina and Anorthosis to the team
column16: which its president denied. Nea Salamina defeated Anorthosis; Olympiacos won the league championship
column17: despite its defeat by Omonia. The Olympiakos board apologized
column18: congratulating Nea Salamina on its victory. By the end of the decade Nea Salamina was finishing mid-table
column19: despite an outflow of players to other teams or the army.

column1: During the first two seasons of the 1970s
column2: Nea Salamina finished in the middle of the table; the next two seasons threatened relegation
column3: which was avoided. The club's low point was 14 August 1974
column4: when the occupation of Famagusta by Turkish troops led to Nea Salamina becoming a refugee club. Fans and players scattered to unoccupied areas of Cyprus and abroad. In October
column5: board members met at the offices of Aris Limassol
column6: deciding to revive the club. Since most players were in Larnaca
column7: it was decided to make Larnaca the club's temporary home. Its offices were housed temporarily at the offices of Alki Larnaca F.C. and in January 1975 acquired a rented building. Expenses were paid with contributions from members and friends of the club. Two youth academies were founded
column9: the CFA decided to schedule a special championship. Although board members were uncertain whether Nea Salamina should play (due to the refugee problem)
column10: they decided to participate so the team could remain in the Cypriot First Division and stay alive. Since there was no permanent stadium
column11: the team used GSZ Stadium in 1974–75

The team's hopes rested both on defeating Enosis Neon Paralimni FC and Evagoras Paphos not to beat AC Omonia or Olympiakos Nicosia FC to lose by Alki Larnaca F.C.. column3: the team finished third and qualified for the Cypriot Women's Cup (losing 3–1 to AEK Kokkinochorion at GSP Stadium). That year it won the Super Cup
column4: beating AEK Kokkinochorion 2–1 at Ammochostos Stadium in Larnaca.In 2007–08
column5: the team finished second. In 2008–09 (when it also finished second)
column6: it forfeited the championship game (at home
column7: against Apollon Limassol) when the referee stopped the match due spectator overcrowding.In 2008–09
column8: Skevi Antoniou was leading scorer in the Cypriot First Division with 64 goals. The women's team disbanded in 2010 for economic reasons.
